intro: Astragalus cephalotes, commonly known as the mountain milkvetch, is a flowering plant belonging to the legume family, Fabaceae. It is native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia and is characterized by its erect, branching stems and small, pea-like flowers. The plant produces pods that contain several seeds, and its leaves are typically trifoliate, consisting of three leaflets. Astragalus cephalotes is adapted to arid and semi-arid environments, often growing in rocky or sandy soils. It plays a role in soil stabilization and is of interest in ecological and botanical studies.
